#â€‹667 â€” December 14, 2023

Read on the Web

âœï¸ Christmas is almost here, so we're preparing our annual roundup issue for next week, before we take some time off! Keep an eye out for that next Thursday :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

Oxlint: A New JS Linter '50-100x Faster' than ESLint? â€” Making tools as fast as possible is a common theme in the JavaScript world, and it's the MO for the JavaScript Oxidation Compiler toolkit. Oxlint is one of their tools thatâ€™s now GA. It's still early days, but when Evan You says â€œthe performance is absolutely nutsâ€ when running against the Vue 3 codebase, we sit up and listen.

Boshen

Bun v1.0.18: The JS Runtime Preparing to Take Over the World â€” I might have overegged the headline, but Bun is on a serious mission to replace Node.js, at least, with their 'one goal for 2024' being to â€œflip the default backend JavaScript runtime from Node.js to Bun.â€ They are also placing a focus on shipping Windows support ASAP.

Jarred Sumner et al.

New TypeScript Courses: Take the Learning Path â€” Join Mike North (Tech Lead at Stripe) for this series of brand new TypeScript courses. You'll get hands-on practice covering both the fundamentals and advanced features like utility types and advanced generics. Learn best practices to configure and evolve your TS codebase!

Frontend Masters sponsor

Visual Studio Code November 2023 â€” The latest VS Code release has some handy enhancements for JS developers, including a V8 heap snapshot visualizer, the ability to drag tabs into their own new windows (a.k.a. â€˜floating editor windowsâ€™), and TypeScript 5.3.

Microsoft

Deno 1.39: The Return of WebGPU â€” Deno introduced WebGPU support in Deno 1.8 but it was removed for various reasons. Itâ€™s back and gives you a tidy way to work with the GPU directly from JavaScript (behind the --unstable-webgpu flag, at least). Improvements to Node.js compatibility and various Deno APIs, as well as TypeScript 5.3, are included.

The Deno Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ GitHub Unwrapped is a fun project that renders your GitHub activity into a video (a la Spotify's "Wrapped" roundups). The source is available. It uses the React-based Remotion to dynamically create the videos.

  • Safari 17.2 is a particularly jam-packed release of Apple's browser, but on the JavaScript side it has added support for import attributes.

  • There's only a day or two left to take the State of JS 2023 survey.

  • The latest Storybook beta has added support for React Server Components.

  • A handy list of JavaScript engines, runtimes, and interpreters.

RELEASES:

  • Million 3.0 â€“ VDOM replacement for faster React.

  • Croner 8.0 â€“ Trigger functions using cron syntax.

  • Rollup 4.9, Ember.js 5.5, Expo Router 3.0 beta, Remix 2.4.

ğŸ“„ Articles & Tutorials

The Await Event Horizon in JavaScript â€” You know someoneâ€™s getting heavy when they start a JavaScript article by talking about the event horizon around black holes and how â€œa similar boundary exists around every JavaScript Promise.â€ Enjoy.

Charles Lowell

Benchmarking, Profiling, and Optimizing JS Libraries â€” As part of this yearâ€™s Web Performance Calendar, take a journey with StÃ©phane to learn about optimizing a library (globalize, in his case) by way of benchmarking and profiling.

StÃ©phane Goetz

[Live Today] Fix Slow Code and Improve Browser JavaScript Performance

Sentry sponsor

The New TC39 FAQs â€” TC39 is the committee responsible for evolving and maintaining the ECMAScript spec, the standardized form of JavaScript, and its members have started a disclaimer-riddled FAQ. You can suggest new topics by opening an issue, or learn a little from the nine questions covered so far, including Will JS ever add JSX notation? and Will WebAssembly replace JS?

Ecma TC39

You Don't Need JavaScript for That â€” â€œJust because you know something needs JavaScript, doesnâ€™t mean it still does. You can make better websites if you test those assumptions every now and then.â€

Killian Valkhof

What Vueâ€™s Creator Learned the Hard Way with Vue 3 â€” Evan You shared some of the lessons he learned from the release and reception of Vue 3 around things like including a lot of small breaking changes, to choosing deprecation over breaking changes.

Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

â–¶  Deploying Node.js with Google's Duet AI â€” Duet AI is Googleâ€™s AI-based assistive agent that works both in the IDE and within Google Cloud.

Google Cloud

Stop Nesting Ternaries in JavaScript
Phil Nash

RE:DOM 4.0: The 2K UI Library â€” We first linked to this library over 6 years ago but itâ€™s still going, so if you want something to help with creating and syncing DOM elements thatâ€™s â€˜close to the metalâ€™, itâ€™s worth a look. v4.0 enables tree shaking and adds viewFactory.

Juha Lindstedt and contributors

TS Docs: Online Reference Docs for npm Packages â€” Browse reference TypeScript documentation for any package or version of a library.

Shubham Kanodia

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You're welcome.

JavaScript Weekly

Learn How Modern JS Frameworks Work by Building One â€” Building things is a great way to learn, even if you donâ€™t end up using what you built. Even better is when someone whoâ€™s already built something successful introduces you to the process. Nolan doesnâ€™t go super deep but far enough to whet your appetite and for you to learn a few things by taking it further.

Nolan Lawson

ğŸš€  Astro 4.0 Released â€” The new major release of the Astro content-site framework is just out, including a new dev toolbar, automatic i18n routing, new view transition APIs, and more. Thereâ€™s also, experimentally, incremental content caching. Upgrading is simple â€“ an npx @astrojs/upgrade away for most folks.

Astro

Streamline API Development With Postman Workspaces â€” Postman workspaces give teams shared access to the API tools they need to solve problems together. They are the go-to place for development teams to collaborate and move quickly while staying on the same page.

Postman sponsor

Maglev: V8â€™s Fastest Optimizing JIT â€” An interesting look under the hood of how the V8 JavaScript engine (as used in Chrome, Node.js and elsewhere) continues to get faster thanks to work on its Maglev JIT compiler which sits between the existing Sparkplug and TurboFan compilers (which both have distinct compilation speed vs code performance tradeoffs).

The V8 Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š The WebAssembly vs JavaScript (PDF) paper compares the energy requirements and performance of JS and WASM on the Web. Spoiler: "WebAssembly is faster than JavaScript and even more energy efficient."

  • The New Stack weighs up the pros and cons of using React today.

  • Talk about going down a rabbit hole, but did you know it's possible to use Nuxt, Vue and Tailwind CSS to build an Adobe Premier Pro plugin?

  • Popular ingress service ngrok has unveiled a JavaScript SDK to add secure ingress to Node apps.

  • The Construct 3 2D game engine now supports TypeScript.

  • Redux 5.0, Redux Toolkit 2.0, and more.

  • Node.js v21.4.0 (Current), Qwik 1.3, and Redwood 6.5

Fabio Spampinato

The Complete Puppeteer Cheatsheet â€” If you want to control a headless Chrome browser from JavaScript, Puppeteer is for you.

Mohan Ganesan

Accelerate Your API Development with Postman Collection Templates â€” Browse 70+ free and customizable templates to jump-start your API design, documentation, development, and testing workflows.

How Marketing Changed OOP in JavaScript â€” A look at JavaScriptâ€™s earliest history and its prototypal nature.

Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Eliminating JS Framework Lock-in with Web Components? â€” Can you build an app where each component is using a different framework? Amazingly, yes. Web components aren't new but are 'having a moment' and Jake demos an interesting, if contrived, use case. He explains: â€œSay youâ€™re writing a Vue app and you really want to use a library thatâ€™s only available as a React component. You can wrap that library in a web component and use it in your Vue app...â€

Jake Lazaroff

Announcing Deno Cron â€” Deno adds a cron-style feature to run code on a pre-defined schedule using Deno.cron. This works locally (behind --unstable) in a long-running process, but on Deno Deploy it analyzes the definition and runs the code on time, as youâ€™d expect, with no extra work needed.

Zinkovsky and Jiang (Deno)

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and Work #LikeABosch â€” At Bosch, we shape the future with high-quality technologies and services to inspire people and improve their lives. And itâ€™s our people who make us remarkable. Our success is your success. Letâ€™s celebrate together. Learn more.

Bosch sponsor

The Biome Formatter Wins the 'Prettier Challenge' â€” Two weeks ago, the creator of Prettier put up a $10k bounty for a Rust-powered code formatter that could pass over 95% of Prettierâ€™s tests. Biome, the toolchain forked from Rome, has already managed to claim the prize, topped up by further contributors.

Biome

ğŸ¤” There's a post from the Prettier POV where @vjeux explains why he offered the bounty: he felt a 'a lack of competition' was holding Prettier back.

  • ğŸ™ï¸ Off The Main Thread is a new podcast featuring Jake Archibald and Surma (both formerly of Google / HTTP 203).

  • ğŸ‚ Not to do with JS â€“ though some of you may use it â€“ but Notepad++ is 20 years old. It's a popular open source code editor and Notepad replacement for Windows.

  • ğŸ™‹ The State of JavaScript 2023 survey is still open to take.

RELEASES:

  • Passport 0.7 â€“ Popular authentication middleware for Express-based apps.

  • eta (Î·) 3.2 â€“ Embedded JS template engine for Node, Deno, and browsers.

  • Fable 4.6 â€“ F# to JavaScript transpiler.

ğŸ“„ Articles & Tutorials

â–¶  10 JavaScript Changes You (May Have) Missed in 2023 â€” Weâ€™ve covered most of these, but this is still a productive refresher in just six minutes, covering things like toSorted(), iOS Web Push, Next.js updates, Angular 17, and the rapid rise of Bun.

Fireship on YouTube

Fireship is a great channel for these sort of quick-fire roundups, and if you want more 100+ JavaScript Concepts You Need to Know is a fun one.

Tracking Frontend JS Exceptions with Playwright Fixtures â€” Playwright is commonly used to test frontend apps and ensure theyâ€™re rendering and behaving correctly, but what if you want to be sure the underlying JavaScript is working as expected too? Stefan has some tips.

Stefan Judis

Lesser Spotted React Mistakes and How to Avoid Them â€” Read about common pitfalls that occur when writing React code. Cut, paste, & try the included examples in your own code.

Sonar sponsor

A Deep Dive into CheerpJ 3.0: A WASM JVM for the Browser â€” A look at an interesting WebAssembly-based Java Virtual Machine that runs client side in the browser, opening up bidirectional Java-JavaScript interop, if you need it. Note that itâ€™s commercial, but can be used free for personal projects and evaluation.

Pignotti, Bates, and De Rossi

A Simple WebSocket Benchmark: Node vs Bun â€” Using as â€˜textbookâ€™ an example of WebSocket communication as possible, the author pits Node and Bun against each other.

Daniel Lemire

Svelte Through the Eyes of a React Developer
Ido Shamun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

FullCalendar: A Full Sized JavaScript Calendar Control â€” An interesting option if you want a Google Calendar style experience for your own apps. Has connectors for React, Vue and Angular. The base version is MIT licensed, but thereâ€™s a commercial version too with extra features.

Adam Shaw

Knip 3.3: Find Unused Files, Dependencies and Exports â€” Finds unused files, dependencies and exports in your projects and lets you cut/knip them away.

Lars Kappert

ğŸ˜ Knip has continued to evolve a lot this year, and now also has a snazzy new homepage. You can also learn more about what's new in 3.x.

Inline REPL Anywhere in Your Code â€” Execute context aware code snippets directly in your editor, anywhere in your project, even if your application/tests are not working.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Syntax.js: Code Syntax Highlighting Library â€” There are many long standing options in this area, such as Prism and highlight.js, but itâ€™s interesting to see a fresh and lightweight take.

William Troup

ai2html: Turn Adobe Illustrator Files into HTML â€” We noticed this tool being used by the Financial Times to share graphs they've designed, and the result is really good. This project isn't new, but we haven't shared it before, it's well maintained, and there are lots of examples.

The New York Times Company

aws-lite: A New Node.js-Powered AWS API Client â€” AWS does a good job with its APIs and tooling, but sometimes their approach is a little heavyweight. aws-lite provides a simpler, faster option. â€œYou can think of it as a community-driven alternative to AWSâ€™s JavaScript SDK.â€

Begin

Hire Vetted Developers in US Time Zones, Fast

Revelo sponsor

  • Neutralinojs 4.15.0 â€“ Cross-platform desktop app framework â€“ lighter than Electron as it uses the locally available browser engine.

  • jest-image-snapshot 6.3 â€“ Jest matcher for image comparisons.

  • Mongoose 8.0 â€“ MongoDB object modelling approach.

  • edit-in-place 1.9 â€“ Edit in place library for Angular apps.

  • Jotai 2.6 â€“ Simple, flexible state management for React.

  • sql.js 1.9 â€“ SQLite 3.44 compiled to JavaScript.

  • React Share 5.0 â€“ Social media sharing buttons.

  • np 9.0 â€“ A better npm publish.

  • pnpm 8.11 â€“ Fast, disk space efficient package manager.

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œAs a principal engineer, I view it as my role to keep us off the bleeding edge as much as possible. That way, when we really do need to innovate, we have the capacity to do so. And when we don't need to, we can go really freaking fast.â€

___
Nicole Tietz
